audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker introducing "Flat Earth Clues, Part 7, The Long Haul," presenting it as a series helping understand the Flat Earth system and the deception around it. He mentions focusing on the southern hemisphere or landmasses close to the outer ring, crediting a fellow flat-earther for the title. The tone is informative and conversational.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker who begins by stating he's giving a summary of a video. He emphasizes a practical approach to showing someone how to "view the flat earth," using an example. The male speaker's tone is informative and calm.

The audio begins with a male speaker announcing the intention to reveal how strange the world looks through the use of online resources, math, time, and mental effort. He speaks conversationally and in a friendly tone, and explains the process, noting that writing is optional and that he will provide necessary information and links.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker providing a list of websites to help calculate distance, mentioning that phone GPS systems and apps can also perform this function. He reads out several website names in a straightforward, informative tone. He adds that people can use more familiar tools like Google Maps.

The audio begins with a male speaker introducing a plan to examine two groups of cities. He then identifies the first group as being from Australia and New Zealand, specifying that it will include Melbourne, Sydney, Perth, Auckland, Christchurch, and Hamilton; the speakerâ€™s tone is informational.

The audio features a single male speaker with an informative tone, who introduces a group of South American cities, all located in the Southern Hemisphere, mentioning that higher altitudes may not work. He then lists the cities: "Rio de Janeiro Brazil," "Sao Paulo Brazil," "Brasilia Brazil," "Buenos Aires Argentina," "Lima Peru," and "Santiago Chile." He concludes by mentioning a link in the description with other airports.

A male speaker with a measured, explanatory tone discusses interchangeable groups of concepts, mentioning that "the results will be the same" and presenting an example involving fellow flat-earthers. He describes taking elements from two groups to obtain distances, and encourages listeners to consider a bent route accounting for the Earth's curvature. The speaker contrasts an expected straight shot over the South Pacific Ocean with starting on the opposite side, citing Cape Town, South Africa, and a globe Earth distance.

The audio begins with a male speaker commenting on "a straight shot through the Indian Ocean," suggesting it's an easy route while looking at a map. The speaker then mentions trying to book a flight and suggests using "Travel Math." He clarifies that other similar services would work as well, as they're all connected to the same system. The audio concludes with silence.

The audio clip begins with one male speaker stating, "and this is when everything goes wrong." The speaker describes a flight where the airline sent him "4700 miles almost due north to Dubai." He suggests they may be picking up people but finds it excessive. The speaker concludes that he is "probably comfortable in my seat drinking vodka tonics anyway."

A man is speaking in a casual tone, discussing a complicated flight itinerary. He mentions flying from Dubai and expecting to go straight to Auckland, but instead being rerouted to Melbourne, then finally to Auckland. He notes that he's rounding the distances for simplicity.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing flight details, noting the unexpectedly long mileage and travel time, before questioning how long the trip should have taken. He then suggests someone might consider the incident isolated, characterizing airline issues. The speaker continues, claiming that the situation is not an isolated incident, suggesting unfairness. The clip concludes with a brief transition into background music.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker providing the first part of a clue, mentioning the "utter lack of non-stop flights" and referring to "multiple cities in each group." He highlights a "plot hole," explaining how you "can't get a single non-stop flight" from cities like Sydney, Rio, or Santiago. He describes his experience trying to find a flight, comparing it to a "casino game" with connections constantly "coming in like spam windows." He provides examples like "Start in Christchurch, go to Auckland," and mentions that some connections took "over 50 hours." He encourages the listener to try it themselves and warns that "the strangeness doesn't end there," as "the speed is wrong."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker referring to an "optimum cruising speed guide" from a pilot's forum that lists "all the international aircraft used in these routes." He mentions a "triple seven," describing it as a "state of the art flagship plane," with a cruising speed of "640 miles an hour," estimating that 7400 miles would take "around 12 hours." He then questions this distance, saying, "It doesn't exist," and adding that "the closest I came was a one connection flight with a three hour layover" and the total flight time was 20 hours. He concludes by saying "20 take away three is 17, not 12." The speaker sounds analytical and somewhat frustrated.

The clip features a male speaker discussing airplane speeds, suggesting that certain speeds wouldn't work because they are slower than those of even older Airbus models. He then introduces the concept of the "flat earth map" to illustrate his point. The tone is conversational, but turns analytical as he describes the map and implies manipulation through flight connections. The speech is followed by a sudden dramatic musical cue, consisting of a simple melody that evokes suspense and mystery.

The audio clip features one male speaker discussing the potential for pilots to notice inconsistencies in their navigation, emphasizing the need to "ignore the world GPS system." He quotes the history of GPS as "developed in 1973 to overcome the limitations..." He ends by noting it was created by the Department of Defense. The speaker sounds analytical and conversational.

A male speaker discusses how the implementation of GPS in 1995 would have made picking up a breadcrumb trail challenging for pilots. He questions who a pilot would tell if they thought something was wrong, emphasizing how someone would hesitate to believe the entire map system was wrong, comparing it to claiming an alien spacecraft followed a plane around. The tone is skeptical.

The clip begins with a male speaker with a casual tone, inviting listeners to "start playing Flight Time Casino for yourself" and discover interesting things. He suggests sharing it with pilots, excluding any mentions of "flat earth", and encourages independent research, providing an email and phone number for contact. The clip concludes with a brief, simple chime sound.
